text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with braised black lentils that's
right i've gotten so many requests for
this in fact it's a little suspicious
why am I getting so many requests for
lentils is there something going on with
the lentils I don't know about maybe but
who cares this is so delicious and one
of my favorite side dishes of all time
and the good news is it's really easy
and relatively quick to put together so
here we go let's start by melting a
little bit of butter in some olive oil
over medium heat and then we're gonna
add some mirepoix which is fancy French
culinary terminology for a dice of
celery carrots and onions i have roughly
equal parts of each although the exact
ratio is not that big of a deal you know
why cuz this is just a vegetable side
dish so you can relax
all right we're also gonna give it a big
pinch of salt and we're just gonna sweat
that on medium heat for i don't know
seven eight minutes we just want the
onions to kind of turn translucent and
for those veggies to soften and sweeten
up a little bit so just let them sweat
in that butter and oil give it a stir
once in a while and while that's
happening I'm also gonna add a good
amount of fresh thyme I'm just gonna go
ahead and throw the whole sprigs in
there I hate picking thyme leaves it's
one of the most time consuming annoying
herb related tasks ever so I don't do it
I throw them in whole and then later
we'll just pick out the stems it's a
perfect system and you could also use
rosemary here you could use oregano lots
of stuff but times my favorite and by
the way I'll be making no time puns why
too easy
alright so at this point our onions are
getting translucent our veggies are
softening a little bit that time flavors
being infused into that oil and butter
and we are almost ready for the lentils
so we're gonna turn the heat down to low
I'm gonna give it a nice big shot of
freshly ground black pepper and then
we're gonna measure out a cup of black
lentils check it out they're so pretty
and if you think they look good now
where do you see when they hit that oil
and butter they turn jet black they get
shiny and they look like
beluga caviar which is one of the
nicknames for black lentils Beluga
lentils which is one of the problems
with this dish
I love lentils but I like beluga caviar
more so it always makes me a little
melancholy that I'm not eating you know
half a pound
of beluga caviar but that's okay this is
so delicious I don't actually feel that
bad so we're gonna dump the lentils in
we're gonna stir them around and then
it's time to add the liquid now
generally it's about two parts liquid to
one part lentils although I go a little
less than that because there is moisture
in those vegetables so the lentils will
absorb some of that so I'm going to dump
in my liquid I'm using chicken stock you
could certainly use water or vegetable
stock if you're one of those people you
know we don't judge here at food wishes
at least publicly I do judge a little
bit behind your back all right so we're
gonna give that a stir
we're gonna raise the heat up to
medium-high and we're gonna bring this
to a very gentle simmer and once it
comes up to that simmer I want you to
back the heat down to low until it's
just barely bubbling like that
alright about as low as simmer as you
can go we're gonna cover that and this
is gonna cook until the lentils are
tender and have pretty much absorbed all
that liquid it's gonna take roughly 3035
minutes
although exact time will vary so you
gotta keep an eye on it and what I like
to do after about 20-25 minutes I'll
take off the lid
I'll give it a stir I'll kind of see
where I'm at I'll check that liquid
level of course if it seems like it's
getting a little too dry add another
little splash of stock but this one
seemed fine if I see all those time
leaves have fallen off the stems I'll
pick those out and you're probably
wondering why didn't you just use your
freakishly small wooden spoon isn't it
obvious
I want it to burn my fingertips dunna so
I'm gonna pull those out you may want to
give it a little nibble to see where
you're at mine weren't quite tender yet
so I'm gonna put the lid back on give it
another 5 or 10 minutes and like so many
things we cook when it's tender
you're done and don't be scared if you
see a little bit of wetness at the
bottom of the pan that will continue to
be absorbed into the lentils even after
you turn off the heat now some people
like to continue cooking this until it's
much softer I don't really enjoy it as

vinegars very nice in this that really

very important addition I'm also going
to add some freshly chopped parsley
we cooked in some time flavor but I do

course you have to taste this for salt

mine
I'm not saying and that's it look at

and like I said earlier one of my
